title: When Does Bhakti Flourish in the Heart? | Sri Jai Chaitanya Dasa | SB 1.1.20 | 18.07.2024
speaker: HG Jai Chaitanya Dasa

segments.key_quote: Lord Shri Krishna was not that type of incarnation. He was actually the personality of broadhead from the very beginning of his appearance.
segments.summary: The speaker establishes Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead from birth, contrasting this with modern, self-proclaimed incarnations.

segments.key_quote: So, knowledge of the transcendental nature of the birth and deeds of Lord Shri Krishna is sufficient for liberation.
segments.summary: Knowing Krishna's transcendental nature leads to liberation, as described in the Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: So he was selected to speak. What was spoken by Sukadeva Goswami?
segments.summary: The speaker describes the setting of Srimad Bhagavatam, with the sages of Naimisaranya inquiring from Suta Goswami.

segments.key_quote: So it is a time-tested process of Krishna Consciousness or time-tested process of spiritual life where one can advance and get to the goal of life which is liberation from this material body, liberation from this material world.
segments.summary: Bhagavatam is presented as a time-tested path to liberation through Krishna consciousness.

segments.key_quote: Brahma has concluded that Ishvara is Paramakrishna. Ishvara is Krishna and he has Sat Chit Ananda Vigraha.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna's form is eternal, full of knowledge and bliss, contrasting it with the limitations of the material body.

segments.key_quote: So these group came up which stopped talking about all these mythological story or just saying that all these are stories
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the rise of impersonalism through the Arya Samaj movement, which rejected the personal form of the Lord and dismissed Puranic stories.

segments.key_quote: Because the Shudra mentality is always exploitation.
segments.summary: The speaker explains why the Vedas were traditionally kept from those with a 'Shudra mentality' due to their tendency to exploit knowledge for selfish purposes.

segments.key_quote: And the Vedic Shastras are such that only if you accept an authority you would get the knowledge.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the Vedic principle of accepting authority with the modern 'Shudra mentality' that rejects any form of subservience.

segments.key_quote: The Lord is a person who doesn't care that he is a Lord. He doesn't care if you accept me as God or not, because I am God.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Krishna's indifference to being recognized as God with the desire of human 'lords' to control and manipulate, and discusses the difference between truth and purchased popularity.

segments.key_quote: So the latest trip is to call oneself Guru. That is the latest trip. I can't call myself Bhagavan.
segments.summary: The speaker critiques the modern trend of self-proclaimed gurus who prioritize popularity over scriptural truth.

segments.key_quote: so Krishna came for peace deal Krishna came Mahabharata explains the whole way how Krishna appeared in the great assembly huge assembly of all great kings
segments.summary: The speaker recounts the story of Duryodhana's attempt to capture Krishna, highlighting the asuric mentality that refuses to surrender to the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: because they have establish the truth that Krishna is the supreme Lord through their experiences in their life they have realized that human body is so limited human life is so limited we cannot anyway become God
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the realization of great sages regarding Krishna's supremacy and the necessity of surrendering to Him for our well-being.

segments.key_quote: bhakti reveals bhakti itself we need to start bhakti when we start a little bit of bhakti more bhakti is revealed and we do when we do that more bhakti another more bhakti is is established in the heart so bhakti establishes bhakti but we need to start and where do we start with sraddha
segments.summary: The speaker explains that bhakti reveals itself and is self-sustaining, starting with faith (sraddha).

segments.key_quote: we are not able to fan the bhakti because we are giving importance to ourselves ourself when you say we are not giving importance to the soul if we are giving importance to the soul then that becomes our own self interest and that is needed but when we don't know who you we are when we think i am my intelligence when i think i am my ego where i have my priorities when i think that i am a mind which has his preferences and non-preferences then we cannot surrender
segments.summary: The speaker explains that self-importance hinders the growth of bhakti, and that surrender is impossible when we identify with our ego and mind.

segments.key_quote: But real bhakti means I do it because Krishna is pleased. The more I do, Krishna is pleased.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the various false identifications that prevent pure bhakti, emphasizing that real bhakti is performed for Krishna's pleasure, not for self-gratification.

segments.key_quote: But a self-realized person is he who sides with truth always. Whether the truth is popular or not popular.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts siding with popularity versus siding with truth, highlighting that Bhagavatam and Gaudiya Vaishnavas prioritize truth over popularity.

segments.key_quote: Bhagavatam gives us the strength not to change the mind. Bhagavatam gives us the strength that Krishna is absolute.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of unwavering faith in Krishna's supremacy, regardless of changing public opinion.

segments.key_quote: but bhakti is such that only when we put Vaishnava's guru and Krishna first we get bhakti so this is something which has to be practiced.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that absolute knowledge is realized by prioritizing Vaishnavas, Guru, and Krishna above oneself.

segments.key_quote: we get hit when we come for our happiness we never get hit when we come for Krishna's happiness so it's the most important point we have to come to Krishna Krishna consciousness for give me happiness to Krishna Rishikesh Rishikesh seven we understand that he is a master of the senses and we had to understand that our senses are for his satisfaction otherwise it is becoming Ulta I am the God and he is a servant I either God is being very happy
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the common misconception of seeking personal happiness in Krishna consciousness, emphasizing that true fulfillment comes from serving Krishna's satisfaction.

segments.key_quote: He is seeing what was behind that. Bhava grahi janatana. He is always bhava grahi janatana.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Krishna is concerned with the bhava (devotion) behind our actions, not the material offerings themselves.

segments.key_quote: When you make the Lord the center, you are the object and the subject.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the importance of making the Lord the center of our lives, understanding that we are the object of His attention and service.

segments.key_quote: We are not here to come to ask. We are here to give.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of giving to Krishna, rather than asking for personal benefits, and discusses the love inherent in the Lord's chastisement.

segments.key_quote: So our purpose is to come to Krishna to see what I can give, not what I can take.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the importance of giving to Krishna and seeking His pleasure, explaining that true enjoyment comes from being part of Krishna's enjoyment.

segments.key_quote: The real knowledge is surrender. Not ask. Give.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of surrender and giving in Krishna consciousness, and seeking the association of those who speak the truth.
